course.subject: ECON
course.name: Money and Banking
course.description: Theories of money supply and demand; role of money in business fluctuations, inflation, and growth; banking, financial intermediation, and money supply; targets and instruments of monetary policy; rules versus discretion.
course.prerequisites: (ECON 3014 OR ECON 3113) AND (ECON 2123 OR ECON 3123)

reviews.author: hihilex
reviews.title: If you are not good in maths, don’t take this course
reviews.comment_content:
Useless, totally useless
The theories are so abstract, all are mathematical concepts and frameworks, so if you are not good at maths, stay away from this course
reviews.comment_teaching:
He basically reads out what is on the PPT + lecture note, with explanations on his abstract maths equations and framework, remember to copy down as they may be useful for HW and exams

Very boring and most people skipped his class
reviews.comment_grading:
I got full mark in HW (mostly copy from previous HW set)
Mean for midterm, but screwed up on my final exam (total 6Q I did only 2Q, other 4Q I was basically bullshitting as I cannot recall any maths framework or concept to those question)

Prof Zhu has emphasized he (may) use absolute grading for this course and he expects us to get at least 60 marks or above, but honestly the final exam was way too hard for me and turns out I got a C- :) no one knows whether it is really absolute or curve grading
(But at least I managed to pass this course for graduation, thanks Prof Zhu for his mercy on me)
reviews.comment_workload:
Moderate
All the HW he will give sufficient time to complete, provided that some of the questions are recycled from previous HW sets, so not so difficult
But once you over rely on the answers, you will not be able to complete the final exam, the midterm was still fine as most questions were variations of HW set questions. And once you expect the final is in similar pattern, you will GG because the final is totally another story, questions that you have never encountered.

Btw, all midterm and finals are close book:) you have to remember all the difficult maths equation and apply them, luckily this sem is online mode exam, if on site exam, I will just sit in the exam hall and cry in front of the TA T^T

reviews.author: Szczesny
reviews.title: More like a 3-credit course in terms of workload
reviews.comment_content:
Everything taught here is quite pragmatic yet shallow as this course won't dig too deep into a topic.

Intro to Money and Finance
Business of Banking
Banking Regulation
Banking Industry
Central Bank Operation
Central Bank Strategy
Exchange Rates
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Cook did not look particularly prepared for classes which can be reflected by his articulation during his teaching, and he didn't manage to create a vivid learning environment due to his monotone in the 9am class. He is not the enthusiastic teacher that you are looking for, but he is definitely more than willing to answer students' question during and after classes.

His slides was poorly designed and disorganised, you could find errors in his slides occassionally. Graphs and data in his slides are not important at all, but make sure you can grasp the key ideas behind them, like trend of a graph, as they will be tested during exam.
reviews.comment_grading:
His grading is better than I expected, just like other economics professors. Due to the special arrangement this semester, grade a student receive depended on whichever mid-term+hw or final+hw letter grade is better out of the two letter grade. I got +0.95 s.d. for my midterm and nearly full mark for hw. No result released for final, which I think I did pretty poorly, therefore,  I believe midterm+hw will be the combination that decides my final grade. Professor claimed that he would apply absolute grading in this course. Considering the fact that I didnt do a expectional job in my midterm,
receiving an A is an "overrated" grade for me, still, I would like to thank Professor for his generosity.
reviews.comment_workload: Really low. Firstly, I really don't think students have to attend classes at all since his slides included everything even though it is disorganised. Everything he taught during the class was simply repeating whatever has been stated in the slides. Secondly, there were 4 homeworks throughout the courses and each took me about 2 hours at max if attempted seriously, and the TA was quite lenient in marking our work, therefore, not much time needed for checking and polishing our answers.

reviews.author: GodSaveTheQueen
reviews.title: Need to attend every lesson
reviews.comment_content:
The content before midterm is mainly about how central banks run, what targets they have set and the way they achieve it. After midterm, prof would shift the focus to banking, discuss the business model of commercial bank and how they reduce the risks.

Overall, the content is pretty easy yet abundant, we have to memorise lots of names and concepts (Name of central bank in different countries, what is MBS etc), since everything in the lecture notes and he taught in the lesson would be examined.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Lecture notes is pretty messy and not well-organised, sometimes it’s hard to get the main point of each slide.
Prof always update the PowerPoint twice a week, so if you have to print out the notes for study, you will find it troublesome.
It’s necessary to attend every lesson, since prof will explain some complicated concepts thoroughly where lecture notes only show very brief explanation.
Textbook is useless and sometimes maybe misleading.
reviews.comment_grading:
4 assignments in total: 20%
1 midterm: 30%
1 final exam: 50%

Grading is not bad.
Almost everyone manages to get full mark in assignments.
Midterm (full mark 30)
Mean 23.2 High 29.5 Low 11.5 SD 4
My score is roughly 25.
* Allow one page cheat sheet.
Final exam (Not released)
* Allow two pages cheat sheet.

The good thing about this course is Prof will upload past papers of many years. It’s not hard to predict the format and questions he would pick in the coming exam. So, I end up getting an A.
reviews.comment_workload: The only workload is the 4 assignments, but prof encourages us to finish it in a group and he also gives plenty of time, so it’s very easy.

reviews.author: Bini
reviews.title: Interesting course but also a dense one
reviews.comment_content:
This course provides an introduction to money, banking and financial markets. It examines how financial markets work, how financial institutions work, the role of money and the role of monetary policy in an economy.

Lecture 1: Interest rate determination
Lecture 2: The equity price, risk premium, rate-of-return dominance
Lecture 3: Financial intermediation: the asymmetric-information analysis
Lecture 4: Banking, liquidity-provision, and government safety net
Lecture 5: Money, central bank, and conduct of monetary policy
Lecture 6: Monetary policy and foreign exchange rate
Lecture 7: Monetary Policy, fiscal policy, and inflation

Each chapter discusses a specific economic model framework and its sophistication; Every model begins a small, basic set of variables. Then, the model becomes sophisticated usually through integrating more factors or considering special economic circumstances. The objective is to derive a robust conclusion which can be applied to relatively complicated real life situations.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Attendance is mandatory- The pace of class gets increasingly faster as the content becomes more complex. Though, Professor Zhu is willing to slow down to answer whatever questions you might possibly have.

During class, he mainly goes through the PowerPoint slides, which are mainly the summary of detailed notes he uploads on Canvas. To be honest, merely relying on classes to fully grasp the content can be really challenging, mainly due to the nature of this course; there are  A LOT of variables that you can easily lose track of even if you zoned out for a short time. The models require quite a lot of logics (not necessarily math-related), hence I highly recommend you to read through the notes before class, so you are not as lost (it is normal to be lost in this class).

The pace of his class can be fast sometimes, BUT his vocal pace is REALLY slow, which does give you time to catch up on the content but also rid you of the will to listen.

If you are expecting a fun, interactive class full of discussions, you might want to think twice. If you are not really interested in the course topics in the first place, this course could be A LOT of work for very LITTLE fun. Due to the professor's teaching style, self-discipline becomes really important.
reviews.comment_workload: A lot of work for sure. Though homework sets are quite easy to handle (most of the students have the answer keys. Make sure you get one!), mid-term and final exams require a thorough understanding of the concepts and the ability to adjust the model frameworks under different economical conditions. During online semester, the exams were closed-book, and memorizing ALL model frameworks was seriously quite a lot of work but at the same time an ineffective way to learn. So... if you want a chill, light course, this course is not for you! Though, if the topics intrigue you and you are ready to spend some time studying them... go for it!

reviews.comment_teaching: he talks too slow so everyone basically skips lessons and watch lecture videos with faster speed
reviews.comment_grading:
better than expected
all homework nearly full marks for everyone
midterm above mean less than 0.5sd and final slightly below mean
group project slightly above mean
I got a B
reviews.comment_workload:
The homeworks 80% same as source so not difficult to finish.
final is cumulative so need more time for revision.
group project is 5 person per group and the topic is related to the monetary policy decision during the covid-19 of a central bank, the central bank would be decided by your group. reviews.author: goschoolbybus
reviews.comment_content:
Before the midterm, this course focus on understanding how central banks use their powers, the macroeconomic theory that underlies the decision making of central banks and their effect on the economy and financial markets.
After the midterm, the course focus on the economics and institutions of banking. The professor also introduced banking system in China and in Hong Kong.
I personally think the contents are interesting and useful.
reviews.comment_teaching:
It is really hard for me to focus on online teaching while the professor's extremely slow speaking speed made even harder to focus. The good thing is we can watch lecture video in x1.5 speed.
But the most annoying thing for me is the professor will change slides right before the class, so it is useless to print the slides out before the class.
However, the professor is super nice as he has lots of office hours and he is willing to explain every question you have. Make use  of the office hour!
reviews.comment_grading:
Professor said he doesn't do curving in this class so I guess it is absolute grading, although he did not tell us the cut-off. Since we did online this semester, he added new things to the syllabus which are presentation and written report. Professor will give lots of past paper and also a reading package before exam. So it is easy to predict the questions in the exams.

5 hw: 20%
written report: 10%
presentation: 15%
midterm: 20%
final: 35%

My performance:
hw: 19.7/20 (mean:18.2/20)
paper: 10/10 (mean:8.8/10)
presentation: 15/15 (mean:13.1/15)
midterm: 68/70 (mean: 54.7/60 sd:14.37)
final: 91/100 (mean:69.45/100 sd:16.6)
grade: A+

My friend got overall 90% and he got A. So I guess (not sure) the cutoff is 95% for A+, 90% for A, 85% for A-. As we can see the mean will be around 80% which should get B+. Thus, I think this is a good grade course.
reviews.comment_workload: I think the workload is very light compared to other 4-credit course. Only five assignments and you can work with a homework partner. I spent about one hour on each assignment. Presentation and written report are easy to handle as well, just follow what he taught in the class.

reviews.author: maddie123
reviews.comment_content: A study of how banks deal with moral hazard and adverse selection under incomplete information. The second half of the course talks about how central bank influences the market. We have to look at HK, US, China and Europe markets. Quite useful for students to have a comprehensive understanding of the monetary policy.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. would write down notes on whiteboard during lesson for students to follow better. He could usually explain concepts clearly. However, the sequence of his lecture notes is a bit messy. Recommend students to print out lecture notes to class.
reviews.comment_grading:
Assignment x 5: 20%
Midterm: 30%
Final: 50%

Stats:
Students usually score above 3.5% for each assignment
Midterm:
Mean 43.8 SD 9.9 (me: 45)
Final:
It was changed to online exam as school ended early.
MC: we did a Canvas online quiz (3 parts) during 08:30 -11:30; including short calculations, mc, comparison
Long Q: we were given 12 questions at 5pm the day before MC & short Q, due on noon the next day
I've got almost full mark in MC & short Q, long Q result was not released
Final grade: A
reviews.comment_workload: Super light workload for a 4-cred course. Plenty of time was given to finish the assignment. Preparation for midterm was ok as you can bring one A4 cheatsheet. Recommend a brief review after each week to make sure you understand the content well.

reviews.author: Verlaski
reviews.title: Economics is all about mathematical models
reviews.comment_content:
This course is more oriented toward economics other than finance, it also requires a lot of maths so students should really spend time on it and attend lectures in order to know the steps of each derivation. It covers mainly three topics. The first topic is about the fundamental theories of financial markets including interest rate determination and equity risk premium. The second part is about the asymmetric information and moral hazard which contributes to the significance of financial intermediation. The last part is about monetary policy, foreign exchange rate and a little content about fiscal policy.
Throughout the course, mathematical models and derivations are the main roles so do not miss even one class otherwise you are hard to keep up with it. As long as you have a full understanding about the models it's easy to get a high grade,
The assignments only cover what we learn from class and no other content will be covered.
What it does not cover is those about financial aspects, which may be important to students apart from economics program.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor is very kind to students who approach him after class and always gives good explanations to our problems.
Professor is strict about classroom regulation so do not chat in class.
reviews.comment_grading: Mean score of midterm is 60, mean score of final is 57. I got 75 in midterm (lots of unnecessary mistakes in calculation and missed one class of which the content was coverd) and 92 in final. After checking the exam paper I found that the professor actually gives as much as he can and did not deducts all points of wrong answers.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is moderate with four assignments and each covers only those mentioned in class as well as in lecture notes.
Since no cheat sheet is allowed, more time should be spent in reviewing.
No quiz, no project.
